Situation1: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story:
I pushed my cleaning cart down the long hallway, the scent of disinfectant trailing behind me. My supervisor had been clear: every room needed to be spotless, especially the ones checked out this morning. As I entered 304, I noticed a wallet on the nightstand, half-hidden under a magazine. My job was to clean, not to meddle, but I couldn’t ignore it. I picked it up, intending to hand it in, but curiosity got the better of me. It was thick with cash—more than I’d seen in months. 

A voice inside reminded me of my Christian values: honesty, integrity, doing what’s right even when no one is watching. But another part of me, tired and struggling to pay bills, whispered that no one would know if a few bills went missing. The pressure to meet my cleaning quota pressed on me, but so did the weight of my faith. I stood there, wallet in hand, torn between the expectations of my job and the teachings I tried to live by, my heart pounding as I wrestled with what to do next.
